Title:
Mutualism Between Triplaris and Pseudomyrmex: Phylogeny and
Geographical Distribution.
Keywords:
ant-plant mutualism; genealogical sorting index (GSI);
geographical distribution; phylogeny; Pseudomyrmex; Triplaris
Abstract:
The association between the myrmecophyte Triplaris and
ants of the genus Pseudomyrmex is an often reported example of
mutualism, albeit poorly studied. In order to increase our knowledge of
this symbiosis, the interspecific relationships of Triplaris were
reconstructed using five molecular markers (two chloroplast and three
nuclear), and the relationships of the associated Pseudomyrmex using two
molecular regions (one mitochondrial and one nuclear). The phylogeny of
each organism was reconstructed using two approaches: a single
individual per species and a multiple individual per species phylogeny.
The phylogenies of the ants were then compared to that of the plants.
Using a multiple individual phylogeny can provide a finer resolution to
the patterns of association between the two organisms. A data set with
all the collections of plant hosts and resident ants known were also
compiled and mapped their locations using GIS. The pattern of
distribution of both organisms reveals that there are varying degrees of
host specificity; one species (P. dendroicus) is confined to a single
species of Triplaris, while other ants showed broader host usage. This
could be a result of geographical or ecological sorting.
